poem:
### Sunshine in Sète

Where shutters hang like eyelids in winter's slow blink,  
Sète draws open the light, a sunlit drink,  
Oyster shells cradle secrets of ocean's tease,  
As truffles root earthy whispers beneath the trees.  
With muscat in hand by Canal Royal's gleam,  
Winter's a sun-spun, salt-sweet dream.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Sète: the seaside town with year-round sunshine in the south of France While much of southern France closes its shutters for the winter, the fishing port of Sète comes alive. The oyster and truffle seasons are in full swing and bright, sunny weather makes it the perfect place to sip a glass of muscat on the banks of the town’s Canal Royal. The main town on the Thau archipelago, 17 miles (27km) south-west of Montpellier,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
